meanings.definition: To deceive or swindle someone, especially in a playful or harmless manner.
meanings.sent1: Tom was jackrolling his friend by pretending to be a ghost during the campfire story.
meanings.sent2: The mischievous kids were jackrolling each other by hiding fake spiders in their backpacks.
meanings.sent3: The siblings enjoyed jackrolling each other with silly pranks on April Fools' Day.
meanings.sent4: Her smooth talk and quick wit allowed her to jackroll unsuspecting strangers into buying useless trinkets.
meanings.sent5: The magician's ability to jackroll the audience with his sleight of hand tricks amazed everyone.

meanings.definition: The act of playing a prank or practical joke on someone.
meanings.sent1: During the school picnic, the students planned a hilarious jackrolling of their teacher by filling his office with balloons.
meanings.sent2: The classic jackrolling of putting a whoopee cushion on someone's chair never fails to bring laughter.
meanings.sent3: The office prank war escalated when someone pulled a jackrolling by covering the boss's desk in sticky notes.
meanings.sent4: The group of friends organized a massive jackrolling event, leaving fake spiders in every corner of the house.
meanings.sent5: The annual family reunion always included a friendly jackrolling competition to see who could come up with the best joke.

meanings.definition: A form of light-hearted teasing or mocking.
meanings.sent1: The siblings engaged in playful jackrolling, poking fun at each other's fashion choices.
meanings.sent2: At the comedy club, the comedians used jackrolling to entertain the audience with witty banter.
meanings.sent3: During the talent show, the emcee added a touch of jackrolling by playfully imitating the contestants.
meanings.sent4: The group chat was filled with friendly jackrolling as friends shared funny memes and jokes.
meanings.sent5: The TV show included a segment of good-natured jackrolling between the hosts, keeping the viewers entertained.
